author: ansgar.eth
content:
ACDE agenda for today: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1854#issue-3768158167

Mostly just continued Glamsterdam scoping decisions. We are getting close to the finish line!

author: christine_dkim
content: for any devs wanting the latest cfi'd eip list for glamsterdam based on decisions coming out of today's acd call, here's a gdoc spreadsheet for that: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ifXjsiFFzQW8s1gl4Gz3kVDKE2pvTMkPslHuE3U7Nqk/edit?pli=1&gid=285165395#gid=285165395

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
I did some leg work for 7903: Remove Initcode Size Limit and it turns out the Jumpdest analysis is not an issue anymore, because we increased the gas cost of create by 2 gas per byte in 3860.
I am still against fully removing the limit, but we can in my opinion safely increase the initcode limit significantly (e.g. 10x). Bumping the contract size limit needs further investigation though imo.

author: jochembrouwer
content:
Regarding the code size limit, could you or another client provide an image which:
- bumps max code size to 32 kib
- bumps initcode limit to 64 kib (or removes it)

(like https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7954). The goal is to figure out the impact of increasing code size.

Then we can test like https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/blob/d618e5259a06179d7556af1961166cb7bc5da1e6/tests/benchmark/compute/instruction/test_account_query.py#L123 (EXTCODEx on unique contracts) on the 24 / 32 kib contracts to see the impact for EXTCODEx and
https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/blob/d618e5259a06179d7556af1961166cb7bc5da1e6/tests/benchmark/compute/instruction/test_system.py#L53 xCALLx opcodes doing the same
NOTE: target contract is a random code contract which starts with a STOP. We can (should (?)) expand this by also putting JUMPDEST analysis here. I am not sure if clients cache these jumpdests, but we can change the contract factory such that it deploys (unique) jumpdest contracts. The contract will JUMP to the end of the code (which has a valid jumpdest) so we force clients to either lookup or perform the JUMPDEST analysis

author: jochembrouwer
content: I'd rather run this analysis on all clients though

author: cperezz.eth
content:
<@508125616940515329> this is exactly what I introduced in https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/pull/1961

The entire setup is done via spamoor already (running on bloatnet currently): https://github.com/ethpandaops/spamoor/pull/161

So I already ran that for no-state (Geth in dev mode with DB in fs not memory). Here are the results: https://hackmd.io/V-rZ9Wg0To6FpnjWIQWsmA (there's a bunch of graphs, still need to write down all the explanations but wanted to collect the results in bloatnet first).

So I'd suggest to not duplicate work. I will take this branch from Marius and extend the benchmark for sizes up to 256kB (if <@360491619402776577> you can enable it in Geth which I assume is the case already in the PR).
